Award.AwardTitle: AF: Medium: Towards Provable Bounds for Machine Learning

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Many areas of machine learning (ML) currently rely on heuristic algorithms with no performance guarantees, and, in fact, the underlying problems are computationally intractable. The proposed project will lead to new machine learning algorithms with provable guarantees. The PIs will leverage theoretical ideas from average case analysis, semi-random models, approximation, solution stability, and approximate linear algebra, and develop new tools and techniques. Benefits from this endeavor will occur across fields. Theoretical computer science will benefit by gaining new problems and research agendas, and further development of algorithmic and mathematical tools. Machine learning will benefit by gaining new models (hopefully, more tractable than the ones currently in use), new modes of thinking, and new algorithms. The task of proving bounds on algorithms will provide insight into when they do or do not work, as well as suggest modifications to existing heuristics.

The project will involve training a new generation of graduate students and postdocs who will be fluent both in theoretical algorithms and machine learning. The PIs gained experience in delivering this kind of training and mentoring during the past couple of years and will continue this, including working with the undergraduate students. The PIs will disseminate the ideas of this project by lecturing, teaching, and creating new course materials, including videos. One specialized workshop will also be organized, devoted to the topics of study. Open-source software implementation will be released based upon any new learning algorithms that are discovered.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Machine learning has had great empirical success but theoretical understanding has lagged. The project “Towards Provable Bounds for Machine Learning” completed by PI Sanjeev Arora in collaboration with Moses Charikar shed new light on how to design algorithms with provable performance guarantees for many machine learning problems. The provable guarantees can involve running time, solution quality, or properties of the final solution obtained.

 

The problems included several that arise while obtaining automated understanding of natural language, especially topic models, nonnegative matrix factorization, word embeddings, and sentence embeddings. The project resulted in efficient and practical algorithms for learning topic models as well as using a learnt topic model to understand the themes of a presented document.

 

New provable guarantees were also obtained for fundamental computations such as singular value decomposition and Langevin Monte Carlo optimizations, whose utility span many problems.

 

The project resulted in new insights in word embeddings, a basic notion in natural language processing, and the results were published in leading journals of that field. These new insights led to new methods of capturing the meaning of a sentence or a paragraph, which then proved useful in understanding fMRI scans of human subjects ---specifically, in understanding the mapping from the fMRI scan to the movie scenes they were watching. This work was published in a leading journal in Neuroscience.

 

New theoretical understanding was also obtained for Generative Adversarial Nets (GANs), an active new area of research in deep learning that concerns learning deep generative models for complicated objects such as real-life images. Work done as part of the project shows that there are potential lacunae in our understanding of such models, and that the training of such models can in principle appear to succeed even when the learnt distribution is very far from the real distribution. This work, as well as supporting empirical evidence, received a fair bit of attention in the GANs world.
